awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Global Biodefense (PERC-GB)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

This Planning Grant project is focused on activities that will identify and bring together the technical and practical expertise necessary to address the major societal challenges of biodefense. Biodefense challenges, like infectious diseases and bioterrorist attacks, can have a direct impact on individuals, as well as serious consequences for agriculture. This has a direct impact on the food supply and food security.  A national priority to address these growing public health, economic, and societal threats is research and development that enable the 1) rapid detection of infectious agents/toxins, 2) rapid diagnosis, 3) rapid production of medical countermeasures, and 4) rapid and efficient deployment of these medical countermeasures.  In addition to being rapid, these technologies must also be cost-effective and deployable under a variety of resource-limited situations. The planning grant will advance the field of biodefense by bringing together faculty, students and stakeholders from different disciplines to address technical needs.  It will also support education through the involvement of undergraduates and graduate students in the planning grant activities. The planning grant activities will help identify research directions needed to protect lives and preserve animal and plant health in the face of natural and intentional biological threats.

The goals of the planning grant activities include (1) a detailed understanding of the basic science, engineering, computational, social science, workforce development, innovation ecosystem, and diversity and inclusion components needed to address this societal problem; (2) identification of strategic academic, industry, and governmental partners, as well as specific areas of expertise needed, unique existing facilities and testbeds required for success; (3) identification of the stakeholder community, establishing relationships with them, and using their knowledge base to inform (1) and (2) above; (4) independent evaluation and refinement of the concept of the proposed NSF ERC; (5) development of a center identity (i.e. name, vision statement, goals, strategic model), and (6) creation of an effective leadership/management structure.  These benefits are not possible without bringing faculty and stakeholders together in person. These interactions will establish areas of partnerships in convergent research, identify gaps and prioritize activities and strategies for an ERC.  The planning grant activities will culminate in a 2-day workshop, bringing together faculty from the partner universities, stakeholders from industry, governmental agencies, funding agencies, non-profits, community and workforce development organizations along with students. In the end, planning grant activities will establish a stronger, crystallized vision for the scope, leadership structure, team, partner network, and activities of an Engineering Research Center in Global Biodefense.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the biggest challenges that society faces today is protecting lives, human health, and social order in the face of naturally occurring emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, and intentional acts of bioterrorism. The vision of our proposed Engineering Research Center (ERC) is the development and implementation of convergent technologies capable of providing detection, diagnostics, and medical countermeasures to protect people, animals, and plants against biological and chemical threats. To address these growing public health and societal threats, research and development of transformative basic science and engineering technologies, workforce development, and innovation ecosystems are needed that enable the 1) rapid detection of infectious agents/toxins, coupled with 2) rapid diagnosis of disease in patients, 3) rapid production of medical countermeasures, and 4) rapid and efficient deployment of these medical countermeasures.  In addition to being rapid, these technologies must also be cost-effective and be deployable in a variety of geographical locations with varying biomanufacturing infrastructure.

Although the above goals were written in our ERC planning grant in 2018, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, they have never been more urgent than today in the continuing fight against SARS-CoV-2 as well as other emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases.

Through this project we have held three workshops to further develop the convergent research theme(s), identify the team and partner/stakeholder network, formulate a leadership and center structure that is built on diversity and culture of inclusion, and propose initial research thrusts, workforce development, and innovation ecosystem activities of the center.

The first workshop was held on December 18-19, 2018, at UC Davis (both in person and on Zoom) entitled “Solutions Through Highly Integrated Engineering and Life Science Through Defense (SHIELD), NSF- Engineering Research Center Proposal Development”.  This workshop was designed to help the team prepare for the submission of the NSF ERC Preliminary Proposal. The goal of this workshop was to help focus the scope of the NSF ERC proposal and to define priority areas and unmet research, workforce development, and innovation needs related to the topic. This was also an opportunity for team building, refining the research scope of SHIELD, and for identifying overlaps and synergies with other on-going efforts, stakeholders we need to consult, and critical gaps in center expertise.  There were 42 participants from 9 universities and 3 industries. The agenda included an introduction to global biodefense in the age of synthetic biology, overview of expertise and facilities related to biodefense of the core university partners, research capabilities of proposed affiliate university and industry partners, and interactive visioning and innovation session break outs for Research, Engineering Workforce Development, Diversity and Culture of Inclusion and Community Engagement, and Creating and Nurturing an Innovation Ecosystem Thrusts for the SHIELD ERC proposal.  This workshop was instrumental in helping the team prepare and submit an NSF Engineering Research Center Preproposal entitled “NSF Engineering Research Center for Solutions through Highly Integrated Engineering and Life Sciences for Defense (SHIELD),” which unfortunately was not invited for a full proposal.

The second workshop, held at Colorado State University on April 18-19, 2019 entitled “SHIELD Knowledge Innovation Workshop”, was intended to help the team prepare for a full NSF ERC proposal but since we found out just a week prior to the scheduled meeting that our team had not been invited to submit a full proposal we instead used this opportunity to discuss the panel reviews, consider alternative funding opportunities for the center, conduct team science training, discuss ideas for a white paper and discuss next steps for a SHIELD center, as shown on the attached agenda.  This was a working meeting facilitated by the Institute for Research in the Social Sciences (IRISS) and the CSU Science of Team Science Team (SciTS) at CSU with 44 participants (in person and remote) from UC Davis, Tuskegee University, Colorado State University and partners at Purdue, George Mason University and UC Berkeley. The major outcome of this workshop was an NSF preliminary proposal for an NSF proposal entitled “Solutions through Highly Integrated Engineering and Life Sciences for Defense - Science and Technology Center (SHIELD-STC)” which the team submitted in June 2019. 

The final workshop was held on October 27-28, 2022, at UC Davis (both in-person and on Zoom) entitled “Pandemic Engineering for Accessibility and Community Engagement (PEACE)”. The goal of this workshop was to bring together researchers working in pandemic engineering to communicate new research results, identify funding opportunities and research themes, and to catalyze new research collaborations. We had over 90 participants, with representatives from 10 universities, a national laboratory and several government and funding agencies including BARDA, BioMADE and USDA.  

These workshops have brought new faculty and graduate students from UC Davis, Tuskegee University and Colorado State University, as well as other universities across the country, into the interdisciplinary field of biodefense and contributed to their professional development, networking and teaming.
